pr_title: fix #2338 Add new Emission FAIL_ZERO_SUBSCRIBER error code

timeline.bodyText: shouldn't we check subscribers == EMPTY even before attempting to lazily create a queue? Otherwise, it still returns OK if the queue has the capacity but there are no subscribers
timeline.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: One of the advertised features of the EmitterProcessor is the capacity to buffer a (few?) elements into that queue before failing with overflow, including when trying to emit before anybody's listening. If the queue has the capacity but there are no listeners, the first listener will get the early emission from the queue, so this is intended.
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText: Have you considered naming it hasSubscribers?
timeline.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: actually, since there's no direct need for it in this PR it should probably be debated in a separate issue 🤔
replies.author: simonbasle

timeline.bodyText: to avoid double CASing, we can/should replace it with do { read + switch + cas } while (casFails)
timeline.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: done, let me know if that's what you had in mind

timeline.bodyText: IMO this is wrong and should return FAIL_ZERO_SUBSCRIBER
timeline.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText: the fact that UnicastProcessor allows to pre-emit (a few) elements before the actual subscription occurs is IMHO a cornerstone of it working so well as the plumbing for widowing operators. I fear doing what you suggest would open the door to all sorts of issues in windowing operators, at least.
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: if so, the second emission should fail with OVERFLOW and not "zero subscribers" because the sink/processor isn't subscriber-dependent
replies.author: bsideup

replies.bodyText:
why? the whole point of adding this failed state is to indicate undeliverable emission (as opposed to deliverable-in-case-of-later-subscription). there are still 0 subscribers when the second tryEmitNext occurs, but that one cannot be buffered for the benefit of a deferred subscriptions, so we return FAIL_ZERO_SUBSCRIBER (to distinguish from "there's a subscriber but it hasn't requested enough").
		/**
		 * Has failed to emit the signal because the sink has never been subscribed to [AND]
         * has no capacity to buffer the signal.
		 */
		FAIL_ZERO_SUBSCRIBER;
(I should change the above wording to say has currently no subscriber maybe rather than `has never been subscribed)
replies.author: simonbasle

replies.bodyText: IMO the failure's cause is the overflow. The fact that it overflows when there are no subscribers is an implementation detail. Getting FAIL_ZERO_SUBSCRIBER after OK is super weird and IMO counterintuitive 😅
